<bitrise-navigation> + <bitrise-footer> Web Components

Self-contained custom elements that load the Bitrise navigation bar and footer from Webflow within isolated Shadow DOMs. Host-page styles cannot leak in, and the components' CSS cannot leak out.

Quick Start (no framework)

Drop these lines into any HTML page:

<!-- 1. Place the elements where you want the nav and footer -->
<bitrise-navigation></bitrise-navigation>

<main>...your content...</main>

<bitrise-footer></bitrise-footer>

<!-- 2. Load the component script (once — registers both elements) -->
<script src="https://web-cdn.bitrise.io/bitrise-navigation.js"></script>

That's it. Each element:

  1. Attaches a Shadow DOM to itself
  2. Injects a shared loader script that fetches the pre-built HTML + CSS payload
  3. Renders its content inside its shadow root with full style isolation
  4. The navigation additionally wires up dropdown hover, mobile hamburger menu, and keyboard interactions

React Integration

Custom elements work natively in React. Since <bitrise-navigation> has no props/events that need special binding, you can use it directly in JSX — React treats unknown lowercase tags as custom elements.

1. Load the script

Add the CDN script to your index.html: 

<!-- public/index.html -->
<head>
  ...
  <script src="https://web-cdn.bitrise.io/bitrise-navigation.js"></script>
</head>

2. Use in JSX

export default function Layout({ children }) {
  return (
    <>
      <bitrise-navigation />
      <main>{children}</main>
      <bitrise-footer />
    </>
  );
}

3. Optional: TypeScript support

Add a type declaration so TypeScript recognises the elements in JSX. This form works with both React 18 and React 19: 

// bitrise-navigation.d.ts
import 'react';

declare module 'react' {
  namespace JSX {
    interface IntrinsicElements {
      'bitrise-navigation': React.DetailedHTMLProps<
        React.HTMLAttributes<HTMLElement> & { position?: 'sticky' | 'static' | 'smart' },
        HTMLElement
      >;
      'bitrise-footer': React.DetailedHTMLProps<
        React.HTMLAttributes<HTMLElement>,
        HTMLElement
      >;
    }
  }
}
